person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: State and Private Forestry, Forest Service

description.narrative: CRANE HABITAT CONSERVATION IN MONGOLIA AND CHINA FOR AGRICULTURAL PURPOSES AND BETTERMENT OF THE ENVIRONMENT

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: State and Private Forestry, Forest Service

description.narrative: From March 12-19, 2016, the USDA Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), International Technical and Regulatory Capacity Building (ITRCB) Center conducted a workshop that was structured after similar US-based training with classroom and laboratory exercises which provide participants with a solid understanding of economically important diseases of animals and how to intervene in their control. The components of the TAD Workshop included: 1) introduction of participants to the major emerging and transboundary animal diseases that affect global trade in animals and animal products and thus impact food security; 2) review of international organizations and standards which regulate animal agriculture trade; and 3) practical hands-on field experience in necropsy techniques, sample collection, on-farm cleaning/disposal and general biosecurity for a variety of species.

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses
Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses

description.narrative: The Food for Progress Program provides for the donation of U.S. agricultural commodities to developing countries and emerging democracies that are committed to introducing or expanding free enterprise in their agricultural economies. The program has two primary strategic objectives: (1) increase agricultural productivity and (2) expand trade of agricultural products.

title.narrative: Scientific Cooperation Research Program - Wheat Crop Precision Farming Technique for Mongolian Agronomic Conditions

description.narrative: The Scientific Cooperation Research Program supports joint research, extension, and education projects lasting up to two years among domestic and international agricultural professionals. These projects address issues including agricultural trade and market access, animal and plant health, biotechnology, food safety and security, and sustainable natural resource management.
